ðŸ“˜ Indefinite Articles Table


Now we learn indefinite articles: a/an â†’ ein / eine We will also use this same table format for: - mein (my) - dein (your) - sein (his) - ihr (her/their/formal your) Letâ€™s focus on a/an for now.

This table shows how the indefinite articles ein / eine (a/an) change based on gender and case in German. These are used when talking about a non-specific item.


(S) refers to Singular and (P) to Plural. Indefinite articles technically donâ€™t exist in plural, but we show placeholders here to help you build mental patterns for possessive articles later (like mein, dein).

CaseMasculine (S)Feminine (S)Neuter (S)Plural (P)
Nominative
(Subject)		eineineein(m/d/s)eine
Accusative
(Direct Object)		eineneineein(m/d/s)eine
Dative
(Indirect Object)		einemeinereinem(m/d/s)einen

ðŸ§  Note: There is no plural form for indefinite articles but here we mention plurals so that we can use this table later on to make sentences with Poessive articles like my your his etc.

Letâ€™s make sentences with the indefinite article (a/an) just like we did with definite articles:

I have a ball â†’ Akkusativ maskulin
ich habe einen Ball 
  I play with a watch â†’ Dativ feminin
 ich spiele mit einer Uhr 
 wir haben eine Tasche (we have a bag) â†’ Akkusativ feminin
 he comes with a car â†’ Dativ neutral
 er kommt mit einem Auto 
You can use the table above to find the correct form of ein/eine/einen/einem/einer

Now letâ€™s make the same table useful for possessives like 'my', 'your', 'his', etc.

Translations:
my = mein
your = dein
his = sein

We will cover ihr (her/their/formal your) later.

All possessive forms follow the **same endings** as the ein/eine table.
Just add a prefix:
+ m for mein
+ d for dein
+ s for sein

So:
A ball - ein Ball (Nominativ maskulin) 
 My ball - m+ein Ball â†’ mein Ball (Nominativ maskulin)
I come with a Car - Ich komme mit einem Auto (Dativ neutral) 
 I come with my car - Ich Komme mit m+einem  Auto â†’ Ich komme mit meinem Auto (Dativ neutral)
 Similarly 
 s+eine Uhr â†’ seine Uhr (Akkusativ feminin)
d+einen Stift â†’ deinen Stift (Akkusativ maskulin) 
 You can see that we have only added the appropriate prefix to what would be the word for indirect article

Letâ€™s see example sentences with mein / dein / sein:

ich komme mit meinem Auto (I come with my car) â†’ Dativ neutral
er liebt seine Uhr (He loves his watch) â†’ Akkusativ feminin
Sie haben deinen Stift (You have your pen) â†’ Akkusativ maskulin
sein Buch ist blau (His book is blue) â†’ Nominativ neutral

Summary:

1. Use the same table for a/an, mein, dein, sein, etc.
2. Identify the case (Nominativ, Akkusativ, Dativ)
3. Find gender of noun (maskulin, feminin, neutral, plural)
4. Use correct ending from table
5. Add prefix for mein, dein, sein, etc.

Examples:
- einen Ball â†’ meinen Ball (my ball)
- einer Uhr â†’ meiner Uhr (my watch)
- einem Auto â†’ deinem Auto (your car)
